ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Understanding of Nash equilibrium, games, auctions
Fairly thorough exposition of game theory at an intermediate level.
Learned about how to model and analyze games with perfect information and imperfect information

The formalism of games, combinatorial game theory, solution and equilibrium concepts, applications to economic models, zero-sum games, repeated games, Bayesian games, auction theory, and mechanism design.
Backward induction, Nash equilibria and subgame perfection, correlated equilibria, repeated games, Bayes-Nash games and auctions
I learned a lot about the theoretical side and real world applications of game theory.
how to analyze games and model situations as games
Game Theoretic Reasoning
A mathematical look at game theory.

I learned a lot about how t mathematically model game theory, and found this very interesting myself. This course was an interesting mix between applications and very mathematical theory. Some of the classes would be spent on very rigorous mathematical proofs (separating hyperplane theorem, theorem. of the alternatives, etc.), while others would be spent solving. different types oof games, and finally. we. saw several applications in the buyer/seller problem, models of firm competition, auctions, and mechanism design.
Gained the toolset to think critically about economic games, and to analyze them.

None. absolutely zero. truly one of the most useless courses to take at yale if it's not required for your major. Theoretically, the material should be interesting but the manner in which it was taught makes the material feel useless.
A diverse range of game model mechanics applicable to a variety of real world situations from auction pricing to infinite interactions.
knowledge of NE, zero sum, and other important game theory classes
I learned general strategies for solving games in an abstract and theoretical way.

I learned a lot about game theory and how game theorists think about problems and try to find solutions by applying game theory. I enjoyed learning how to find Nash Equilibria, correlated equilibria, mixed-strategy equilibria, and learning about zero-sum games, bargaining, backward induction, and repeated games. The class is mathematical but also very applicable.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Professor Strack is very knowledgeable
Weakness: we were shown a lot of abstract math / proofs that we did not need to know for assignments or exams

It felt like the instructor (Strack) was pretty checked out - I get that it's hard to be engaged with a class over Zoom, but he pretty much reproduced his online notes with no deviations every class, meaning that there was no point in ever attending.

The problem sets, while having some good/challenging problems on them from week to week, were sort of trivialized by the fact that the TA would answer every question in detail during office hours. On one hand, this was definitely helpful when the psets coincided with other deadlines. On the other hand, it made it easy to get by with zero engagement with the material. The midterm was also absurdly easy, exacerbating the aforementioned issue.

Overall, I just feel like I learned way less than I expected - 351 is supposed to be the capstone course in a sense for the Econ/Math major, and I feel extremely meh about the experience overall.

Strength -- you learn a lot from nothing. 
Weakness -- I wish we had covered more applications, although I know were limited time-wise!!

I think the problem sets were really helpful in learning the material. I think the grading of the course is a bit strange; there is a much higher level of scrutiny in the grading of answers on the exams than on the problem sets, which made it tough to properly study. Also, the problem sets are, in my opinion, the most substantial part of the class but are only worth 15% of the grade. I think the class could be improved by giving more weight to the problem sets and less to the exams.

Strengths: the first few problem sets were fun as they ask us to solve several simple games.
Weaknesses: not the most engaging lectures, hard to follow

Strengths: Dr. Strack is really sweet and seems to genuinely care about his students. He responded to our pleas to make the PSETS more manageable, and really tried to take student feedback into account. The exams were quite reasonable this year -- hard but doable. The PSETS became MUCH more manageable as the semester went on. The TA was literally amazing and was one of the only reasons I got through his class. Without him working through the PSETS, there's no way I wold have had any idea what was going on. The PSETS were also thankfully graded quite generously. Lastly, the class was fairly well organized and the professor seemed to have things together.

Weaknesses: This class is quite theoretical, so there were definitely lectures where it seemed like we were so far in the weeds, it was hard to know how anything really connected to game theory. Because of the rigorous nature of the class, some of the PSETS were brutally hard. Because of their difficulty, it felt like I got little out of them and was just pure confused. By the end of the class, the material got incredibly difficult. I have no idea what happened the last 3 weeks of class. Some of the concepts were so hard, the professor didn't even consider adding them to the final exam.

The exams had practically nothing to do with the course material. Lectures were extremely abstract and hard to follow, and whenever you asked for help Philipp just told you to read his lecture notes over and over until you got it. Problem sets also had almost nothing to do with the lectures. Felt like I was taking three courses at once and was confused in all of them.

Strengths: Prof Strack is a good lecturer (although sometimes his notation can get a bit confusing and it is also a direct repeat of the lecture notes), since he is clear and very willing to check in and answer questions.

Weaknesses: the PSETs took an insane amount of time (and there was a problem that was basically a full length academic proof). I have no problem with hard PSETs, but I wish that they were slightly easier such that I could figure it out on my own (or part of it) without having to go to OH every single week.

I think one of the weaknesses of the course is that I would sometimes sit down to do the problem set without much of an idea of how to do it, since we were sometimes lacking examples in class. Nonetheless, that improved a lot in the second half of the course after Professor Strack took a mid semester feedback poll. Apart from that, I really enjoyed professor Strack's teaching and also really liked the material.
The initial problem sets were personally very difficult, but near the end they were manageable, both as I got the hang of the psets and because they were easier.

The only strength of this course was the TA 

Weakness: virtually everything else
The lecture is very well taught and the professor is very easy to approach when you have questions.
Difficult concepts but lecture notes r helpful
The course had very interesting and engaging material and problem sets without being unduly difficult. No real weaknesses to the class!

The course is challenging, but has many resources available for students, such as the class lecture notes as well as the teaching fellow. The problem sets usually differed from the precise material covered in class, but this helps students think outside the box a bit. The course could be improved by the professor having a regular office hour along with the teaching fellow.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Worked well - despite COVID

I think the live virtual lecture where the professor wrote along with us worked well. I also found that the scenarios we solved together worked well though class engagement seemed limited to a few individuals.
I think the typed notes published were very helpful and should be continued post COVID.

The recorded lectures are huge! Allow students to go back and supplement understanding. The office hour format of working through things all together rather than answering questions 1-1 was also a LOT better especially in the virtual world.
Everything was pretty standard. Professor Strack expected some level of engagement and participation from the students, which I like on zoom because otherwise it is very hard to pay attention.
Office Hours for problem sets were helpful

The course format was fine; the professor used a whiteboard during class but also had typed course notes available, which was helpful. The teaching fellow recorded office hours, which was nice for this class, since the problem sets could be challenging and there was only one office hour each week.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are a CSEC major this course is required. I came in without game theory knowledge, and this course was very very difficult
Not really, unless you're required to. You'll learn more by taking a class like Econ and Computation.

Yes! It is a lot of work (the pset is difficult) but the material is really interesting. You cover a lot. I also think it is very TA dependent -- our TA saved us each week by guiding us on the pset in his two hour office hours (it essentially became mandatory section).

For the first half of the course, the professor basically repeated the lecture notes verbatim. Problem sets were all over the place, with problems ranging from routine to almost impossible without going to office hours. Exams (although not sure if this was due to the virtual format) felt a bit orthogonal to lectures and problem sets.
If you're an econ math major, it's a required class. The material is interesting, even if it's pretty technical and dry (a.k.a math-heavy). If you've taken 125, it shouldn't be too bad.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student with caution. While I think it is a great way to learn more about game theory, it requires a lot of independent work and some self teaching.

Would not recommend unless required for major. Lectures were tedious and hard to follow with complicated notation which was not always clearly explained. Problem sets were ok with the help of TA section.

Surprisingly, yes I honestly would with Professor Strack. Would I take it if it wasn't a major requirement? Probably not. But for a major requirement, it wasn't too terrible this semester. The class is quite challenging and can be brutally hard at times. The material got quite difficult the last 3-4 weeks and I had no idea what was going on. However, the professor acknowledges this and that material wasn't really even on the exam. Throughout the whole semester for that matter, Dr. Strack was very receptive to student feedback and very approachable. He made the PSETS significantly more manageable as the semester went along. I still probably spent around 10 hours on the PSETS, but rarely significantly more which I appreciated.

Overall, the class this year was definitely loads easier than the class has been before. I have no idea if it'll hold up, but if it does, this class is not the worst requirement in the math/econ major. I support taking this class. Go to office hours and you will be fine.

I mean its required for a few majors so you dont have much of a choice. But honestly, no. I had high hopes for this class but it was so disconnected that there are many other classes I wish I could have taken instead.

I would recommend this course to someone only if you are interested in the mathematical foundations of economics and game theory. If that sounds like you, I think this course is great - it teaches you a lot and helps gain a new perspective on how players interact in games.

If you have an interest in economics and a knack for mathematics, this is definitely the class for you. If you are interested in economics or math, then this course may be challenging, but is definitely doable if you put time towards it and engage with the content.
Not unless its a major requirement. Even then, I think the course should be completely restructured if it's to be continued to be taught.
Only if you need it for the econ-math major. If not, there are other classes where you will learn more with less work.
I highly recommend this class to anyone wanting to learn game theory.
Yes cool topics and challenging
Yes! It is an engaging and interesting class but is not overly difficult and the workload is very reasonable.

I would recommend it, and be aware that though it is mathematical, it does not use very much advanced long-problem math (i.e integration, parametrizations, linear algebra, etc.), although there is some. It is more about using mathematical notation and problem-solving methods to work through the game theory in a quantitative way.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded virtual lecture
There were also weekly office hours by the TA via zoom which became defacto section as well as a couple of recorded lectures.
NA
There were two pre-recorded lectures I believe but the rest were live.
recordeed lecture
Live + recorded
Live lecture was pretty much it. There was also a weekly office hour / section, held live (and recorded) on zoom.
also recorded
Lectures were also recorded.
